questions.prompt: What is the causal effect of a policy that administers iodinated contrast to all contrast-indicated patients, compared to a policy of withholding contrast, on short-term acute kidney injury risk?

For patients eligible for contrast-enhanced imaging, how would the probability of acute kidney injury within 7 days differ under the counterfactual scenario of receiving iodinated contrast versus not receiving contrast?

Among contrast-eligible patients at the time of imaging decision, what is the causal effect of choosing iodinated contrast administration (vs. non-contrast imaging) on subsequent acute kidney injury risk within 7 days?
In patients for whom contrast-enhanced imaging is clinically permissible, what is the causal effect of iodinated contrast use versus avoidance on near-term acute kidney injury outcomes?

At the imaging decision point for contrast-eligible patients, how does administering iodinated contrast causally affect diagnostic yield relative to the accompanying short-term risk of acute kidney injury?
